poem:
### Breath We Cannot See

A veil of unseen  
gray whispers—  
buoyant harm  
floating, sinking  
in the depth   
of lungs;  
more than numbers,  
these silent thieves,  
stealing breath,  
unnoticed,  
quiet as the  
dawn, they gather,  
an invisible  
burden we cannot shed—  
each gasp a silent  
reckoning  
beneath the  
indifferent  
sky.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Air pollution causing 1,100 cases a year of main form of lung cancer in UK More than 1,100 people a year in the UK are developing the most prevalent form of lung cancer as a result of air pollution, the Guardian can reveal. Exposure to toxic air was attributed to 515 men and 590 women in the UK in 2022 getting adenocarcinoma – now the most dominant of the four main subtypes of lung cancer". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
